newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico to investigate HFCS dumping vs U.S. imports.
newsitem.headline: Mexico to investigate HFCS dumping vs U.S. imports.

text.p: Mexico's Trade Ministry said Wednesday it will start a dumping investigation against U.S. high fructose corn syrup (HFCS) imports.

Mexico imports about 300,000 tonnes a year of high fructose corn syrup, according to the Mexican Sugar Chamber, which has complained for months about HFCS being dumped in the country at prices below cost.

The ministry said in a statement it found evidence "that the U.S. imports of fructose enter the Mexican market in supposed conditions of price discrimination and threatened to cause damage to the national sugar industry."

The ministry said unnamed U.S. exporters and importers have 30 working days to respond and present arguments and proof that they consider pertinent to the investigation so that the government has the necessary material to arrive at a preliminary ruling.
Mexico's national production for the November-June harvest is expected to reach 4.365 million tonnes.

Mexico is currently limited to 25,000 tonnes of sugar exports to the U.S. market under rules of the North American Free Trade Agreement, although the amount increases over time as Mexico continues to be a net exporter.
